Posts.Content: Hi Claire, I had my first chemo last Friday, I had EC and have to say the experience wasn't as bad as I'd anticipated, the actual process of it flowing through my veins only took about an hour and wasn't painful.  My husband and I had a good laugh with the cancer nurse and time flew by. However the side effects have been awful.  I have felt fatigued and dizzy and it doesn't appear to be improving.  I had expected to feel a little better day by day.  Fortunately I haven't been sick, not yet anyway.  Tomorrow is my last day of taking steroids and I am hoping then I'll start to feel more like me. I have been eating little and often and think this has helped me not to be sick, steroids do increase the appetite but if you eat slowly and little and often then piling weight on shouldn't be a problem, or so I'm told.  I have found tea and coffee taste awful and have been mostly drinking fruit juices and cordials.  If I want a hot drink I have hot ginger cordial, ginger is supposed to help you not feel sick. Do you have good support at home?  I do hope so, as I don't know what I'd have done the last few days without help from my husband and family.  I would certainly have struggled to make myself meals, though I can summon the energy for simple things like boiled egg and toast. Do remember though everyone reacts differently, and you may not feel fatigued, I hope you don't.  The main thing to do is what your body tells you, if you feel tired go to bed no matter what the time.  Do not try and fight it is what my chemo nurse told me.  I'm also led to believe that after day 10 I will definitely start feel more human, and possibly before. I had my sentinel node biopsy only a week before my chemo and wonder if that has contributed to me feeling so rough.  My tumour hasn't been removed yet as my oncologist is hoping it responds to chemo and shrinks.  Try not to worry about Wednesday, honestly it isn't so bad.  I wish you well and hope your side effects are minimal.  Good luck and let us know how you get on, but I'm sure it will be fine.  The chemo nurses are wonderful and more than happy to answer any questions and allay your fears, they also offer a great back up system, so don't worry you will be in good hands. Best wishes
Posts.Title: What do you wish you'd known before starting chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Delaine, I have a scalp cap but the irritation I suffer is around my hairline. I've just found a gel filled head band which fits around the hairline, secures to the scalp and helps stop wigs from slipping, size is adjustable.  I found on the internet and have ordered it this evening, fingers crossed it works.
Posts.Title: Anyone have tips on wig comfort?

Posts.Content: Hi, I have a lovely wig which fits properly but my head is completely bald and the wig irritates my scalp, it mostly scratches and itches all around my non existent hairline, this means the maximum time I can bear it is two hours.  Can anyone offer any tips on how to make it more comfortable?  I do have a scalp cap but it doesn't help. Thank you Libby
Posts.Title: Anyone have tips on wig comfort?

Posts.Content: Hi Janice, Sorry to hear you are having a tough time on Tax.  I had four cycles of Tax, my last one was 12th Jan and I too had bad S/E's.   Don't suffer in silence as there are things your unit can do to help minimise your S/E's, give them a ring as if they are unaware of how you are suffering they cannot help.  A few days after my first Tax infusion I rang my unit in desperation, I was in dreadful pain, the unit faxed a prescription to my GP for collection, they prescribed extra strong painkillers and other meds to help me get through.  Also my Tax strength was reduced for cycles two, three and four which helped a little.  What are your side effects, and when was your infusion?  Libby x
Posts.Title: FecT-T part and it's side effects

Posts.Content: Everyone here will be there for you, you'll get lots of support.  Ask anything and someone will have experienced it and be able to help you through.  A positive I can offer you is Tax DOES work, my lump has reduced in size considerably, hang onto that fact and it will help.  I know it's miserable but listen to your body and rest, rest, rest.  I gave up on housework and my house was a tip for months (only just getting it back into shape), housework can wait!  Don't beat yourself up, be kind to yourself.  I hope you have support at home as without my OH and dau's I don't know how I'd have managed. Sucking on pineapple, and drinking lots of water helps with the nasty mouth.  The pain in fingers and toes can be eased with a hot water bottle, and I wore thick socks in bed.  Take care, x
Posts.Title: FecT-T part and it's side effects

Posts.Content: Kate, Thank you so much for responding to my plea's! At the moment I feel completely in the dark and your post has helped me understand. Today I scrutinised my cut and it appears to go from my tumour toward my armpit, maybe this is why I am still in a lot of pain?  I have always in the past had a strong pain threshold, and this is why I couldn't understand why I was feeling my pain to be almost unbearable, but considering what you have said and the fact that my incision goes from the tumour to the sentinel lymph node I now understand my pain is normal. Thanks too for the tip on how to navigate the site, eg info button. Much appreciated, from a very grateful fellow sufferer. Kind regards, Libby
Posts.Title: New to the Group and Looking for Answers and Advice

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I am new to the group and looking forward to receiving support and maybe some answers to questions. My name is Libby (age 64); I was diagnosed mid August with grade 3 breast cancer and a 5cms tumour.  Last Friday I had a sentinel node op and I'm still feeling some discomfort, I still have pain, feel dizzy and sick: is this normal please? On Wednesday I have an MRI scan, how long will that take? My first chemo session is Friday, prior to which I have a chemo consultation; what questions should I be asking at the consultation? Any answers, tips or advice greatly received. Many thanks for reading my post. Libby
Posts.Title: New to the Group and Looking for Answers and Advice

Posts.Content: Hi, Previously I was receiving site notifications of new posts, but I'm no longer getting the emails.  I'm sure it's something I've done inadvertently.   Wondering if anyone knows how I can restore the email notifications. Thanks. Libby x
Posts.Title: Site Notifications of New Posts

Posts.Content: Hi June, Thanks for sharing your experiences.  My first chemo session is drawing nearer, and others' comments here are helping me to feel focused and to understand the importance of  staying positive.  This afternoon I have my MRI scan, which will be a piece of cake but a bit boring I expect.  I am scheduled to have six chemo sessions, then either a lumpectomy or mastectomy, whichever is necessary, followed by radiotherapy. I wish you well with your op and the radiotherapy.  You sound very positive which will give you the strength needed for the next stages of your treatment.  I hope I can approach all my treatment in the way you have done. Many many thanks. Must go, have to get ready for my MRI. Bye, and hope to catch you later. Libby
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - very scared and emotional

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, Thanks for your good wishes for my Friday chemo session.  Good to hear your first chemo wasn't as bad as anticipated.  I have chosen not to try the cold cap, and think you brave to try it.  I didn't think I'd cope well with having to stay for an extra hour and a half or so, and found the novelty of a wig quite exciting.  No straightening irons!  how liberating!  I have surprised myself with my attitude toward hair loss as I've always had a fixation on my hair being perfect, and never felt happy with rainy weather as it would make my straightened hair curl, eek! If I cope with chemo as well as you I shall be happy.  I hope you continue to feel better each day and become stronger in readiness for your next session. Yes, I have wonderful support.  My husband is doing all the cooking and food shopping, he's a chef so more experienced than me.  I have two great daughters', one lives close by, but the other is in the South and we are in the North.  My daughter in the South is coming up beginning of October, and both daughters' and I have a wig shopping trip planned, we anticipate making light of it and having a giggle. Thanks so much for your comments, it is good to hear of others' experiences. Good luck, and please keep me up to date with your progress. Libby
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - very scared and emotional

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone who has submitted comments on this thread, reading them has helped me. I wish all who are still undergoing treatment the very best, and all who have finished their treatment the best of luck for a happy and healthy future. I am not looking forward to starting my chemo on Friday but do feel more positive after reading others' experiences, but it is scary!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Kind regards and best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - very scared and emotional

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for your replies, they are much appreciated. My chemo prescription is EC and I do feel nauseous for the first few day after chemo has been administered, but I haven't been sick.  The steroids (I think they're to blame) make me feel agitated and I don't sleep well the days I take them, they also increase my appetite which in turn upsets me as I feel like a glutton. It was interesting to read the comments re blurred vision as my vision was affected last week (had 2nd chemo Friday 21st Oct), but I hadn't made the association to steroids. You are all right of course; I must raise my concerns with my oncology team, not take it upon myself to stop taking them. Thanks to you all, your comments have been most helpful.
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking steroids?

Posts.Content: Hi, Has anyone stopped taking the steroids prescribed for chemo?  If so please can you tell me how you felt, eg better or worse? As I understand it, and not entirely certain I have this right, steroids are prescribed as an antisickness remedy, but I do wonder if they cause more problems than they cure! I will be grateful for others comments, and be particularly interested in the experiences of anyone who stopped taking them. Thank you. Libby
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking steroids?

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, Your conversation with the chemo nurse is interesting, thanks for sharing it. The steroids give me very bad headaches too; they are debilitating aren't they? I will definitely discuss steroids with my clinic (I have an appointment on Monday) I hope they suggest I reduce my dosage. I was prescribed eye drops last chemo session they are the type for dry eyes, and though they have helped they haven't stopped my eyes running completely.  Perhaps they would help you too, the name is 'hypromellose'. I'm pleased you aren't suffering headaches this chemo cycle, and I hope you have a more comfortable time this time around. Take care, and get lots of rest. Libby xxx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking steroids?

Posts.Content: Hi Susan, Am I correct in thinking you haven't as yet had any chemo?  I've had two chemo sessions (another four to come), my experience is the first week after chemo you feel dreadful, second week rather better but as your white blood cells will be low your defences' against infection will be low, third week feel human.  I hope you don't suffer bad side effects, but if you do you won't feel like travelling the first week after chemo. I personally wouldn't consider going abroad whilst still having chemo as believe it's better to be safe than sorry.  I do though admire you for your positivity and your refusal to give in to your illness. Only you can decide what's best for yourself, and if you think the holiday will help you cope better with chemo then it could be something to consider, but as the previous poster has said circumstances may dictate what you are able to do. Good luck
Posts.Title: travel insurance

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for your responses, As I mentioned previously my pain is now manageable since being prescribed stronger painkillers, however I still have aching fingers, shins and feet/toes.  The best way I can describe my pain is: difficulty moving my fingers, my hands, feet and legs feel hot to touch but frozen inside.  The sensation is not relieved by applying heat. Has anyone else had the same problem, and if so were you given anything to alleviate the pain? Gosh, I can't believe how cruel Docetaxol is, of course if it's efective in shrinking my lump the pain will have been worth it, I think!! I am worried that the pain is coming from my nerve endings and the damage to them will be permanent. Please, if anyone else has suffered similar symptoms let me know your coping strategy. Thanks again everyone for your wonderful support along this long arduous journey. Libby x
Posts.Title: Nobody Told Me I'd Feel This Bad

Posts.Content: Hello ladies, Feeling less desperate now as I spoke to a Breast Cancer Nurse this afternoon who was very helpful, she faxed a prescription for stronger painkillers, Ibruprofen, Senokot and Laxidol to my GP's Surgery for collection.  I've taken painkillers and Ibruprofen and feeling a little less pain, hoping for more relief tomorrow.  The BCN explained that the combination of Taxotere and Zarzio caused my extreme pain. Kelly, thanks for your comments they give me hope.  I feel like you - had I known how I'd suffer I would have thought twice about having chemo, particularly as I was told today that I'm scheduled to have three more cycles of Docetaxol, after my next chemo I'll have another MRI scan and if my lump hasn't shrunk then I'll be taken off chemo.  I have to keep positive and believe it will work, otherwise I'll have gone through the ordeal of chemo for nothing.  Has this happened to anyone else - chemo didn't work?  What a flipping depressing thought to think I may have been punished severely by chemo, and still need to have a mastectomy! I'll get some Piriton Kelly, thanks for the tip, I was prescribed Difflam and it does help a little, yes. I'm looking forward to all this being behind me, for some light at the end of the tunnel. You all take care of yourselves, and keep smiling. Thanks again, much appreciated. Libby xxx
Posts.Title: Nobody Told Me I'd Feel This Bad

Posts.Content: I first had two EC chemo sessions and after the second one my body coped quite well, I did feel tired but otherwise OK.  After a routine MRI scan which proved my lump wasn't shrinking I was informed my chemo prescription would be changed to Taxotere/Docetaxol, and Zarzio injections for five days starting the day after my Taxotere was administered. Had my first Taxotere last Thursday, first injection on Friday and subsequent injections yesterday and today, I opted to inject myself rather than a District Nurse call for five days. Last night I began to feel uncomfortable, I had pains in my hands and top of my legs, today I've felt totally exhausted and I'm in so much pain I could scream!  My mouth feels like a sewage and is sore, this is bearable, but the exhaustion, pain in my fingers, feet, legs and back are driving me to insanity.  I also have pains in my tummy caused by constipation, which isn't fully eased even after taking my prescribed Med's. Initially I was told I'd be having six cycles of chemo. I'd be started on EC and my prescription would be changed if EC had no or little effect in shrinking my lump.  Last Thursday the nurse who administered my chemo said I was down for eight sessions, he was very vague and said he'd check for me and let me know - I didn't see him again!!!  I'm now in total ignorance, I don't know whether I have to have another five cycles of Taxotere, or another two and then a different prescription, infact truth be known I know very little. All the uncertainty is getting me down, which I know is not good as we keep being reminded how important staying positive is, but how does one stat positive when feeling under informed?
Posts.Title: Nobody Told Me I'd Feel This Bad

Posts.Content: Thank you lifelover and Helen for your replies and support. I have been trying to contact my BC nurse since Friday who hasn't got back to me. After reading your replies I decided to ring the Hospital and I'm now waiting for them to get back to me, the nurse I spoke to was going to discuss my pain with an Oncologist.  Hopefully someone will contact me soon. Thanks again, you've been a big help.
Posts.Title: Nobody Told Me I'd Feel This Bad

Posts.Content: Isn't it odd Wildbreast how we ladies react differently?  I found EC a piece of cake compared to Taxotere, maybe because I didn't have FEC, not sure why I didn't have the triple, only E&C, I did feel sick for a few days and dizzy too but it was manageable as it only lasted a few days.  Although a week after my first EC I fainted twice and had to stay in Hospital overnight, but after my 2nd EC my body coped much better.  I'm hoping for the same improvement after my 2nd Taxotere.. I'm pleased the Taxotere worked in shrinking your tumour, where are you now treatment wise?  Was a lumpectomy necessary?  Thanks for your good wishes. Take care of yourself. Libby xxx
Posts.Title: Nobody Told Me I'd Feel This Bad

Posts.Content: Fabulous news, Mishka.  I am so happy for you and wish you all the best with your future treatment. Libby x
Posts.Title: Got my results...

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne, Having used the cold cap and your hair still falling out must have been a big disappointment for you.  I didn't have the cold cap so no experience of it, but I have read of others' who have lost their hair after using the cold cap. My hair started to come out in clumps on day 11 of my first chemo, on day 16 I asked my daughter to shave my head as it was distressing seeing my hair on my pillow and in the shower, also from a hygeine point of view I wanted rid of it as it was falling out in the kitchen too.  After my head was shaved I felt so much better.  To be honest losing my eyebrows and eyelashes upset me more than not having head hair.  In the house I go commando or wear a turban, and plonk my wig on to go out.  I've become quite adept at faking eyebrows - there's a good video tutorial on You Tube here's a link ............. http://www.youtube.com/watch?gl=SG&feature=related&hl=en-GB&v=U4lajZWeEyE   You will come to accept your bald head (if you do lose all your hair) and within no time be used to it.  Is your hair long?  If it is long I'd suggest having it cut shorter to give it strength, as you may then with the aide of the cold cap hang on to a lot of it.  At your next chemo session ensure the cap is fitted properly - I've heard of ladies losing their hair because the cap didn't fit tight enough. Try not to worry, and do contact your BCN for her advice.  If you do lose your hair it's ot the end of the world, hair grows back. Good luck and take care. Libby x
Posts.Title: hair loss

Posts.Content: Well done, Tracy.  I hope your S/E's are minimal.  Which chemo regimen are you on?  Make sure you get lots of rest and TLC, and keep warm and cosy. Libby x
Posts.Title: 4th chemo and it all went well

Posts.Content: Lots of styles and ideas here.......... http://www.scarfhut.co.uk/turbans_33.html
Posts.Title: Headwear

Posts.Content: Hi, Sorry to hear your results are worrying you, I cannot directly help you re info but if you read the thread on this link you should find it helpful.  http://share.breastcancercare.org.uk/forum/her2-positive-need-advice-t34118.html Take care, and let us know how you get on.
Posts.Title: her2 positive help

Posts.Content: Hi Lellis, I note you live in West Yorks, I live in Leeds and am being treated by the NHS.  Mid August, I attended the Breast Care Unit at LGI and had a mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy, all were performed on the one afternoon and I was treated with kindness, compassion and respect.  A week later I returned for a core biopsy and a meeting with a Registrar, the Registrar, a lady with the human touch gave me the result of the biopsy - a 5cms tumour, hormone negative, she took time to fully explain exactly what this meant and even apologised for being the deliverer of this shocking news.  I was then introduced to my Breast Care Nurse who took myself and my husband to a very comfortable private sitting room where I was made to feel at ease, Kath, my BCN, was able to answer all questions I put to her and she offered lots of information regarding what would happen, in what order and the reasons why.  Kath gave me her telephone number and said I could ring anytime to speak with her, if she was unavailable I could leave a message on her phone and she would return my call ASAP. A few days after, we took a planned holiday to Italy and returned mid September which did delay my treatment, but I needed the holiday and the Breast Care Team agreed a holiday would be good for me.  An appointment was arranged for me to have a consultation at LGI with an Oncologist who talked me through my treatment regimen, again with a very relaxed approach giving me time to digest all I was being told and ready to answer any of my concerns, or fears.  I was admitbted to LGI on 23rd Sept for a sentinel lymph node biopsy, Kath rang me a few days later and gave me the result of the op - good news all lymph nodes proved negative.  I began my Chemotherapy at Bexley Wing, St James' on 30th Sept.  The Bexley Wing is a fantastic modern Oncology Unit, ALL staff I have encountered are truly wonderful.  A few days after my first chemo infusion I fainted twice and was admitted to a ward on Bexley Wing, I could not have been cared for better, or quicker, I was immediately given intravenous antibiotic and glucose, and every necessary test was carried out, eg - urine, bloods, bloodpressure, chest xray and ECG.  I have been allocated a Chemo Nurse whom I can ring for help or advice, and she too is a little marvel.  Thursday last week I had my 4th chemo infusion; my first two chemo's were EC, this was changed to Docetaxol for my third cycle.  I really suffered with bad side effects for most of the 21 days following my first Docetaxol; it got to the point at day four of my cycle when I felt so desperate I didn't think I would summon the strength to go through it again, I rang the Bexley Unit and was given a telephone discussion with a Chemo Nurse (mine was on holiday), the Nurse listened to my complaints of aches and pains etc, she calmed me down - I had been hysterical - and explained that there was lots of help I could be offered; she said she would fax a prescription to my GP for strong painkillers and other med's, and advised I take a list of all side effects to my next clinic appointment to discuss with my Chemo Nurse, this I did, and the upshot was the Nurse spoke with my Onc who agreed to lower the dosage of my Docetaxol by 20% and spread my dosage of Steroids across more days, these changes have a made a big difference, I am now on day eight of my 2nd Docetaxol cycle, and my side effects though unpleasant are do-able. So, to sum up my experience of the NHS in Leeds: I do not believe I could have been treated faster, more professionally, more compassionately, more kindly or with more respect.  Kath, my Breast Care Nurse still rings me from time to time to ask how my treatment is progressing, and she is genuinely interested.  Susan, my Chemo Nurse, always returns my left messages quickly, never hurries our conversations and always answers my questions.  When my chemo is finished (can't wait), I'll be having either a lumpectomy or a mastectomy (whichever is necessary) at LGI, and my nursing contact will once again be Kath - so continuity.  I cannot praise enough the standard of care and treatment I've received, well done Leeds, and well done NHS. Lellis, I'm pleased you have decided to use both private and NHS as I'm sure you can take the best from both. I think you may find this an interesting read, it's a lady's blog, the lady was treated by both Spire Leeds and NHS, she praises both highly.  http://suzettesblog-suzette.blogspot.com/ I take this opportunity to wish you a journey as smooth as possible, please keep us informed of your progress, good luck. Also good luck to everyone else about to start chemo. Take care everyone, hugs all round.
Posts.Title: NHS or private

Posts.Content: Wow Hilary, Good for you not letting the grass grow under your feet.  I'm sure it will be a big pick up for you and boost your confidence no end, anything which helps you move on has to be good, doesn't it?  You owe it to yourself to do what feels best for you.  Congratulations, and I'm sure you'll look great. Good luck for next Friday's results. Take care. Libby x
Posts.Title: Is botox allowed nearly a month since radio finished?

Posts.Content: Wow Hilary, Good for you not letting the grass grow under your feet.  I'm sure it will be a big pick up for you and boost your confidence no end, anything which helps you move on has to be good, doesn't it?  You owe it to yourself to do what feels best for you.  Congratulations, and I'm sure you'll look great. Good luck for next Friday's results. Take care. Libby x
Posts.Title: Is botox allowed nearly a month since radio finished?

Posts.Content: Hi Mimi, The shop I chose my wig from advised washing it in baby shampoo, and said it's only necessary to wash it about once a month.
Posts.Title: wigs

Posts.Content: Hello, I'm sorry to hear you are feeling let down.  My experience is different to yours; I was given a prescription for a wig which entitled me to a free wig, and given the choice of a few wig shops to choose my wig from.  My prescription was posted to me before my chemo started.  It does sound like you have been overlooked.  You mention ringing your Breast Care Nurse who hasn't returned your call, again I cannot relate to this as my BCN has always returned my calls.  Do you have an assigned Chemo Nurse?  It was my Chemo Nurse who arranged my prescription, but I'm not sure if all Health Authorities operate in the same way.  If you do have a number for your Chemo Nurse I would suggest you ring her, otherwise ring the Oncology Unit for help. Or you could try calling the Macmillan helpline for advice on ... 0808 808 0000.   I'm sure they will be sympathetic and offer you advice as to who to contact. Good luck.
Posts.Title: wigs
